Attend ev'ry nymph of the vale,</br>Whose bosom with sympathy glows,</br>Who can list' to a sad flowing tale,</br>And a tear due to pity bestows.
By the side of a murmuring rill,</br>That meander'd along the gay mead,</br>A swain at the foot of a hill</br>So sweetly attuned his reed.
His song was so mournfully soft,</br>And the cadence so pleasing did flow,</br>Yet a tear from his eyes trickl'd oft,</br>Which proceeded from anguish and woe.
At length a sad silence he broke,</br>And in accents so plaintive began;</br>He call'd on his wandering flock,</br>To give ear to his sorrowful strain.
"No swain once so cheerful as I,</br>My breast was a stranger to pain,</br>From my heart there escap'd not a sigh,</br>Till Amanda appear'd on the plain.
"O'er these meadows how oft did I rove!</br>These scenes, once my chiefest delight!</br>And the linnet, companion to love,</br>Welcom'd each rosy morn to my sight.
"To my crook I may as well complain,</br>Since she will not my passion approve;</br>I foolishly thought (but 'twas vain),</br>That Amanda would listen to love.
"Some swain may with flatt'ry prevail,</br>And gain an access to her heart,</br>But, Amanda, beware of his tale,</br>For 'tis surely gloss'd over with art.
"Ye swains never deem me remiss,</br>For my lambkins how can I endure?</br>May each morning shine fair on your bliss,</br>If from Boreas my flocks ye secure.
"But if on a cold gloomy bier,</br>A pale corse in the grave I am laid,</br>If she'll moisten the sod with a tear,</br>My latest fond hope is o'erpaid."
Then his head on the bank he reclin'd,</br>His reed it lay carelessly by;</br>At Amanda and love he repin'd,</br>And breath'd out his soul in a sigh.</br>
